I'm [AGENT NAME]. Take a moment to introduce yourself.

Click on the Sharing Space to the left. The image shows a metal bar of length L that moves at constant velocity v-> through a magnetic field B-> that points into the paper (as shown by the crosses in the figure).
Redraw the bar, and indicate how the charges in the bar are redistributed due to the force that the magnetic field exerts on them. Upload a URL for your image into the Sharing Space.

This charge redistribution (that you just drew) produces an electric field inside the bar that prevents further charge redistribution. Draw the E-> field lines inside the bar. Upload a URL for your image into the Sharing Space.

Apply Newton’s second law to a charge in the middle of the bar—now it is in an electric field and in a magnetic field, and it is in equilibrium. Draw a force diagram and your mathematical representation, and upload the URL into the Sharing Space.

Use the expression that relates the E-> field magnitude component E_y (direction perpendicular to the velocity of the bar) and the potential difference over a distance ∆V/L with the previous results to determine an expression for the potential difference between the ends of the bar.
Let’s apply this result to a real-life application. Refer to the new image in the Sharing Space.

A major artery has a diameter d of 1 cm. A magnetic flow meter clamped around the artery sets up a region of magnetic field B = 0.20 T. The flow meter measures a potential difference of 2 x 10^-3 V between opposite sides of the artery. Positive and negative ions flow through the artery at a speed v as shown in the diagram.|Discuss and make sure you understand the diagram.

You want to estimate the speed of the blood flowing through the artery. As a first step, draw the force exerted on a + ion and on a – ion flowing in the blood by the external magnetic field. Do you agree on the direction of each force?
Next, draw a charge diagram showing how the + and – ions accumulate on the walls of the artery.
Draw a force diagram for a + ion that travels straight through the middle of the artery because F_(E on q) balances F_(B on q).
Use your equation relating F_(E on q) and F_(B on q) to solve for the electric field magnitude E.

Use the expression that relates the E-> field magnitude E and the potential difference over the diameter of the artery ∆V/d with your previous results to determine an expression for the speed v of the ions in the artery.
What is the speed of the ions?
The activity is complete now. Please paste URL(s) for your results into the Sharing Space and remember to complete the peer marking assignment by ….|Have a great day!
